content: Navy To Christen USNS Wally Schirra The Navy will launch and christen dry cargo/ammunition ship USNS Wally Schirra, Sunday, March 8, 2009, during a 7 a.m. PDT ceremony at the General Dynamics NASSCO shipyard in San Diego, Calif.

content: From Miriam Webster: chris·ten Pronunciation: \ˈkri-sən\ Function: transitive verb Inflected Form(s): chris·tened; chris·ten·ing Listen to the pronunciation of christening \ˈkris-niŋ, ˈkri-sə-niŋ\ Etymology: Middle English cristnen, from Old English cristnian, from cristen Christian, from Latin christianus Date: before 12th century 1 a: baptize 1 b: to name at baptism2: to name or dedicate (as a ship) by a ceremony suggestive of baptism3: name 14: to use for the first time

content: Purification and later ritual cleansing and even later still Baptism are all accomplished with "living water" (water in motion like in a stream or lake) The purpose is to "clean the vessel", (you) for a new "life". Take a new "path". Have a new beginning, or create a new clean "person" for the indwelling Spirit to reside. In fact ALL three of these faith systems have very strong restrictions about blood contamination because of the "life" or spiritual "unknown component" attached to blood. The "Good Samaritan" story gets its importance from the blood bann and the Pharisie and then the Levite refusing to help the wounded man on the rapid approach of the Sabbath, because they may have been contaminated by touching his blood. The "Samaritan" being a Jew but one who was considered by the Pharisies to be "outside the faith" because they did not worship in the temple, and didn't care about religious legalisms, but concerned himself with the true spiritual component of treating the man's humanity and his life, rather than let him perhaps die, but remain ritually pure by ignoring one of God's children. Jesus was all about the meaning of the law, NOT the legalistic ritual value of it, because there IS no ritualistic value, if you don't obey the spirit of it! Perhaps in pre Hebraic times even pre Hammarhabbic times there may have been a "blood" washing of some type but I have never heard of it in relation to any Hebraic, Christian or Islamic ritual. T
reply: Purification and later ritual cleansing and even later still Baptism are all accomplished with "living water" (water in motion like in a stream or lake) The purpose is to "clean the vessel", (you) for a new "life". Take a new "path". Have a new beginning, or create a new clean "person" for the indwelling Spirit to reside. In fact ALL three of these faith systems have very strong restrictions about blood contamination because of the "life" or spiritual "unknown component" attached to blood. The "Good Samaritan" story gets its importance from the blood bann and the Pharisie and then the Levite refusing to help the wounded man on the rapid approach of the Sabbath, because they may have been contaminated by touching his blood. The "Samaritan" being a Jew but one who was considered by the Pharisies to be "outside the faith" because they did not worship in the temple, and didn't care about religious legalisms, but concerned himself with the true spiritual component of treating the man's humanity and his life, rather than let him perhaps die, but remain ritually pure by ignoring one of God's children. Jesus was all about the meaning of the law, NOT the legalistic ritual value of it, because there IS no ritualistic value, if you don't obey the spirit of it! Perhaps in pre Hebraic times even pre Hammarhabbic times there may have been a "blood" washing of some type but I have never heard of it in relation to any Hebraic, Christian or Islamic ritual. T

content: quote: Originally posted by tawodi: If tin whistles are made out of tin....what are fog horns made out of?? Tin whistles are made of steel. Hard on the inside, and deceptively shiny because of the thin layer of tin on the outside. As are fog horns.
quote: Originally posted by tawodi: If tin whistles are made out of tin....what are fog horns made out of??
reply: Tin whistles are made of steel. Hard on the inside, and deceptively shiny because of the thin layer of tin on the outside. As are fog horns.
